title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP01 Understand the lineage of your container image
title: Understand the lineage of your container image
description: It is important to understand what is built into your container image. Starting with a minimal container image will save space and speed up the starting of your container when deployed into production. Many customers create parent images that form the base for what all containers in the organization are built on top of. These parent images are minimal images that put into place requirements and security controls established by the organization.
outcome: Enables efficient development, running, management, and maintenance of containers while maintaining security posture.

title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP02 Have parity between your deployment environments
title: Have parity between your deployment environments
description: A major benefit of using containers is to provide the ability for the development team to develop new updates and features using an identical artifact that runs in production. Development, testing, QA, and production environments should be as similar as possible. All environments should share best practices for everything, with the differences between them being the ability to scale and the data operated upon.
outcome: Ensures consistency across environments and reduces deployment issues by using identical artifacts from development through production.

title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP03 Build the image once and use the same image in all environments
title: Build the image once and use the same image in all environments
description: Once the new image has been built with the updates in place for deployment, promote the same image into the next environment, testing, QA, and production, to provide for consistency across all environments. This will reduce the number of changes introduced in each new environment and provide for more consistent behavior.
outcome: Reduces variability and potential issues by using the same image artifact across all environments.

title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP04 Use a CI/CD build process
title: Use a CI/CD build process
description: Use a CI/CD pipeline to build and test your images through every stage in your development process. The CI process usually starts upon a trigger from a version control system. Steps include checking out code, building the application artifact, building the container image, running tests against the image, and pushing to the target container registry. Once built, continuous deployment takes the recently built container image and deploys it to the target environment.
outcome: Automates the build and deployment process, ensuring consistent and reliable container image creation and deployment.

title: Use multi-stage builds
description: Small container images have undeniable performance advantages. Use multi-stage builds to split the build-phase of the image from the final image that will be used to run the application. With this mechanism, you can create the complete build environment with all the dependencies in one stage and copy only the necessary artifacts into the final lightweight image, achieving reproducible builds with lightweight target images.
outcome: Creates smaller, more efficient container images while maintaining reproducible builds with all necessary dependencies.

title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP06 Implement a minimal container image design to achieve your business and security objectives
title: Implement a minimal container image design to achieve your business and security objectives
description: Build into your container image only what is necessary. Pictures and other static assets should be stored in a data store (e.g., Amazon S3) and served through a content delivery network. This will achieve a minimal container image size, which reduces storage and running host resource requirements, and speeds up the instantiation of a new container from an image.
outcome: Optimizes container image size, reducing resource requirements and improving container startup time.

title_full: CBLDOPS01-BP07 Use package managers to deploy your containerized applications
title: Use package managers to deploy your containerized applications
description: When building a containerized application, the deployable unit can include the container image and its per-environment configuration. Use packaging tooling such as Helm and Kustomize for Kubernetes, AWS Copilot for Amazon ECS, or Docker Swarm for Docker. The target artifact will be a package that contains a reference to the container image and its common configurations across all environments, with per-environment customizations.
outcome: Simplifies deployment management and enables consistent configuration across different environments.

title_full: CBLDOPS02-BP01 Implement health checks to determine container state
title: Implement health checks to determine container state
description: Implement container health checks to enable your orchestration tooling to direct connection traffic to the container only when it is ready to accept connections, or stop routing connections if the health checks show the container is no longer running as expected. The orchestration tooling will tear down the misbehaving container and replace it with a new healthy one.
outcome: Improves workload reliability by automatically detecting and replacing unhealthy containers.

title_full: CBLDOPS02-BP02 Have your logs available outside the running container
title: Have your logs available outside the running container
description: Ensure that the logs generated by your running containers are collected and accessible externally. This will enable you to use log monitors to gain insights into the behavior and functionality of your running container. Your application should be writing its logs to STDOUT and STDERR so that a logging agent can ship the logs to your log monitoring system. Define log messages to be consistently structured to enable correlation of logs across multiple microservices.
outcome: Enables effective monitoring and troubleshooting by centralizing logs and providing visibility into container behavior.
